posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
I hope everyone has been having a great start to the school year! This summer, Team 9312 has developed a new swerve learning minibot called TurdSwerve that we aim to share with the FIRST Robotics Competition community. TurdSwerve is a compact, 3D-printed swerve chassis designed to serve as an off-season bot for teams transitioning to swerve drive or for training rookies and refining code. It works with various motor types, including Neos, Falcons, or Krakens (CIM motors coming soon), and supports thrifty encoders, CANCoders, MAG encoders, or no absolute encoders. Unlike traditional swerve drives, it uses a 3D-printed PLA chassis instead of costly commercial pods, costing around $40 USD if built from spare parts. The design allows for quick, easy swapping of gearing components in under two minutes, minimizing the hassle of screwing everything togetherâ€”a common frustration among programmers.

NERDSwerve, the upgraded version of TurdSwerve, offers a more durable pod design featuring a low-cost swerve bearing, yet still costs under $100 per robot. While the original TurdSwerve design remains available for those looking to save money, NERDSwerve includes enhanced features and a more robust build. Weâ€™ve also released a series of tutorials covering assembly, configuration, and programming guides, accessible via our YouTube channel and the new NERDSwerve website. Check out these resources if you find them useful for your team!

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: super cool. definitely going to have to make one!!

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: It seems like you're driving it pretty hard in the demo video. How long does it last? Is it something you can drive substantially? I'm wondering if it's similar to an alpha bot or off-season drive practice.

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
That is actually only about 50% speed. It is using a full FRC battery and the Krakens are significantly overpowered for the 35-pound robotâ€¦

Driving at that speed typically lasts for 30-40 minutes before we start to experience power issues. A 2-pod robot would likely last longer.

If youâ€™re planning to use it for driving practice, keep in mind its smaller size makes it easier to handle compared to a full-sized robot. You could attach it to a larger main plate if desired. Bumpers may also be necessary.

Regarding longevity, weâ€™ve driven this particular robot for approximately 20 hours and taken it to several outreach events without encountering any problems. The podâ€™s gearing is easy to replace and can be fixed quickly if needed.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: This looks really great! Itâ€™s also a great advertisement for lightweighting. ðŸ˜Š

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: Thatâ€™s so cool! I was curious more about the length of life that the modules have, less so the amount of drive time you get. Do the gears wear over time? How do impacts affect the modules? Side note: how much weight would it support?

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: How long does it last before you need to print replacement gears or other parts?

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
Weâ€™ve been testing our setup for roughly 20 hours without any issues. However, we havenâ€™t subjected it to the rigorous stress that drive practice often brings. I can already feel some wear developing in the drive gears, so we may need to replace them within another 5 to 10 hours of use.  

Our baseplate is made from MDF, and with the current weight of 35 pounds, we shouldnâ€™t add more than 30 pounds on top. Using aluminum or mounting it onto aluminum tubing could support a full 125-pound robot. Just remember, if you decide to widen the baseplate, it might require additional strength adjustments.
Will there be a BOM for the 4-module version?

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: We have just updated the sheet. Sorry about that.

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: The NERD Lock Swerve BOM includes lock nuts, but the CAD reveals areas where lock nuts are too tall and all the nuts are jam nuts. What should be done here?
Hi, is the CIM option still in the plans? This could take the expense to almost zero for our team, which is rather enticing. Either way, thanks for sharing all this!

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: I believe jam nuts are only necessary for an extra electronics deck supporting a 4-pod and horizontal battery configuration. However, they are redundant, so I forgot to include them in the BOM. If jam nuts aren't available, you can skip the corner stilts. There should be no other instances where a jam nut is required. CAD nuts resemble jam nuts because it was simplest to use Onshape nuts, which only had jam nuts available.

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
Extremely importantly, there are still CIM and MiniCIM options available in the CAD. The pod design is identical to the Neo design, but the CIM is slightly wider, causing about 1/16 inch of interference when mounted. This should likely be manageable, though.

We havenâ€™t tested the design with CIMs, so we donâ€™t have any sample code. Adjusting the configuration from the Neo example should be straightforward, however.

While using CIMs is feasible, I strongly recommend going with a brushless motor instead since CIMs lack built-in encoders, which are essential for accurate odometry and autonomous programming. If you have CIMs on hand, NERD Swerve could still work for vision and teleop programming development, though Iâ€™d suggest using brushless motors for more reliable performance.
Thanks! Much appreciated.

posts.name: 3061 Open Alliance Coordinator
posts.cooked: Extremely important. How long does it take to print all swerve modules? What would need to be done to make this as competitive as metal swerves? This is interesting to see; it could help many new teams!

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: On our Bambulab X1C, it takes about 48 hours to print 4 pods out of PLA. The swerve pods, similar to metal swerves, may face durability issues when used on a 120-lb robot. The forks performed well during driving and collision tests but showed signs of wear after 20 hours of high-load use. Printing the gears from PA-CF or another durable material could help extend their lifespan for a competition robot.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Teams have attempted full 3D printing, but as far as I know, all have faced failures, primarily due to gearing issues, and it's not worth the effort for competition bots.

Whatâ€™s the best hardness for the wheels now? From your photos, it looks like youâ€™re using blue wheels with a 50A durometer, but most seem to be at 35A. Since the dualie wheels are around $15, we thought 50A might provide better longevity. Not urgent, just curious about your build progress!

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked: Yes, weâ€™ve seen that 35A wheels wear pretty fast but provide better traction. If you arenâ€™t focused on maximizing acceleration, then 50A wheels would likely be a better choice.

data.title: Introducing NERDSwerve: A Miniature, 3D-Printed Swerve Learning Chassis
